AcquireClusterAdminRole.document: This API can be called to acquire the ClusterRole tke:admin. By setting a CAM policy, you can grant permission of this API to a sub-account that has higher permission in CAM. In this way, this sub-account can call this API directly to acquire the admin role of a Kubernetes cluster.
AcquireClusterAdminRole.name: Acquiring the RBAC Admin role of a cluster

AddExistedInstances.document: This API is used to add one or more existing instances to a cluster.
AddExistedInstances.name: Adds one or more existing instances to a cluster.

AddNodeToNodePool.document: This API is used to move nodes in a cluster to a node pool.
AddNodeToNodePool.name: Moves nodes in a cluster to a node pool

CheckInstancesUpgradeAble.document: This API is used to check which nodes can be upgraded in the given node list.
CheckInstancesUpgradeAble.name: Checks whether the nodes can be upgraded

CreateCluster.document: This API is used to create a cluster.
CreateCluster.name: Creates a cluster

CreateClusterAsGroup.document: Create a scaling group for an existing cluster
CreateClusterAsGroup.name: Create a cluster scaling group

CreateClusterEndpoint.document: Create a cluster access port (intranet / extranet access is enabled for independent clusters, and intranet access is supported for managed clusters)
CreateClusterEndpoint.name: Create a cluster access port

CreateClusterEndpointVip.document: Create an external network access port for the managed cluster (the old way, only the external network port for the managed cluster is supported)
CreateClusterEndpointVip.name: Create an external network access port for the managed cluster

CreateClusterInstances.document: This API is used to create one or more nodes in a cluster.
CreateClusterInstances.name: Creates one or more cluster nodes.

CreateClusterNodePool.document: This API is used to create a node pool.
CreateClusterNodePool.name: Creates a node pool

CreateClusterNodePoolFromExistingAsg.document: This API is used to upgrade a scaling group to a node pool.
CreateClusterNodePoolFromExistingAsg.name: Upgrades a scaling group to a node pool

CreateClusterRouteTable.document: This API is used to create a cluster route table.
CreateClusterRouteTable.name: Creates a cluster route table.

DeleteCluster.document: This API is used to delete a cluster. (Cloud API v3).
DeleteCluster.name: Deletes a cluster

DeleteClusterEndpoint.document: Delete the cluster access port (intranet / extranet access is enabled for independent clusters, and intranet access is supported for managed clusters)
DeleteClusterEndpoint.name: Delete cluster access port

DeleteClusterEndpointVip.document: Delete the external network access port of the managed cluster (the old way, only the external network port of the managed cluster is supported)
DeleteClusterEndpointVip.name: Delete the external network access port of the managed cluster

DeleteClusterInstances.document: This API is used to delete one or more nodes from a cluster.
DeleteClusterInstances.name: Deletes one or more nodes from a cluster.

DeleteClusterNodePool.document: This API is used to delete a node pool.
DeleteClusterNodePool.name: Deletes a node pool

DeleteClusterRoute.document: This API is used to delete a cluster route.
DeleteClusterRoute.name: Deletes a cluster route.

DeleteClusterRouteTable.document: This API is used to delete cluster a route table.
DeleteClusterRouteTable.name: Deletes a cluster route table.

DescribeAvailableClusterVersion.document: This API is used to obtain all versions that the cluster can upgrade to.
DescribeAvailableClusterVersion.name: Obtains all versions that the cluster can upgrade to

DescribeClusterEndpointStatus.document: Query cluster access port status (intranet / extranet access is enabled for independent clusters, and intranet access is supported for managed clusters)
DescribeClusterEndpointStatus.name: Query cluster access port status

DescribeClusterEndpointVipStatus.document: Query cluster open port process status (only supports external ports of the managed cluster)
DescribeClusterEndpointVipStatus.name: Query the progress of enabling the public network port for a managed cluster

DescribeClusterInstances.document: This API is used to query information of one or more instances in a cluster.
DescribeClusterInstances.name: Queries the information of one or more nodes in a cluster.

DescribeClusterKubeconfig.document: This API is used to obtain the cluster kubeconfig file. Different sub-accounts have their own kubeconfig files. The kubeconfig file contains the kube-apiserver client certificate of the corresponding sub-account. By default, the client certificate is created when this API is called for the first time, and the certificate is valid for 20 years with no permissions granted. For the cluster owner or primary account, the cluster-admin permission is granted by default.
DescribeClusterKubeconfig.name: Obtains the cluster kubeconfig file

DescribeClusterNodePoolDetail.document: This API is used to query detailed information of a node pool.
DescribeClusterNodePoolDetail.name: Queries detailed information of a node pool

DescribeClusterNodePools.document: This API is used to query the node pool list
DescribeClusterNodePools.name: Queries the node pool list.

DescribeClusterRouteTables.document: This API is used to query one or more cluster route tables.
DescribeClusterRouteTables.name: Queries one or more cluster route tables.

DescribeClusterRoutes.document: This API is used to query cluster routes.
DescribeClusterRoutes.name: Queries cluster routes.

DescribeClusterSecurity.document: This API is used to query the key information of a cluster.
DescribeClusterSecurity.name: Queries the key information of a cluster.

DescribeClusters.document: This API is used to query clusters list.
DescribeClusters.name: Queries clusters list.

DescribeExistedInstances.document: This API is used to query one or more existing node and determine whether they can be added to a cluster.
DescribeExistedInstances.name: Queries one or more existing nodes.

DescribeImages.document: This API is used to get image information.
DescribeImages.name: Gets image information

DescribeRegions.document: This API is used to obtain all regions supported by TKE.
DescribeRegions.name: Queries the list of regions

DescribeRouteTableConflicts.document: This API is used to query the list of route table conflicts.
DescribeRouteTableConflicts.name: Queries the list of route table conflicts.

GetUpgradeInstanceProgress.document: This API is used to obtain the current progress of the node upgrade.
GetUpgradeInstanceProgress.name: Obtains the current progress of the node upgrade

ModifyClusterAsGroupOptionAttribute.document: This API is used to modify cluster auto scaling attributes.
ModifyClusterAsGroupOptionAttribute.name: Modifies cluster auto scaling attributes

ModifyClusterAttribute.document: This API is used to modify cluster attributes.
ModifyClusterAttribute.name: Modifies cluster attributes

ModifyClusterEndpointSP.document: Modify the security policy of the external port of the managed cluster (the old way, only the external port of the managed cluster is supported)
ModifyClusterEndpointSP.name: Modify the security policy of the external network port of the managed cluster

ModifyClusterNodePool.document: This API is used to edit a node pool.
ModifyClusterNodePool.name: Edits a node pool

RemoveNodeFromNodePool.document: This API is used to remove a node from a node pool but retain it in the cluster.
RemoveNodeFromNodePool.name: Removes a node from a node pool but retains it in the cluster.

UpdateClusterVersion.document: This API is used to upgrade the master component of the cluster to the specified version.
UpdateClusterVersion.name: Upgrades cluster

UpgradeClusterInstances.document: This API is used to upgrade one or more work nodes in the cluster.
UpgradeClusterInstances.name: Upgrades cluster nodes

members.name: ClusterType

members.name: ClusterNodeNum

members.name: ProjectId

members.document: Tag description list.
members.name: TagSpecification

members.document: Cluster status (Running, Creating, or Abnormal)
members.name: ClusterStatus

members.document: Cluster attributes (including a map of different cluster attributes, with attribute fields including NodeNameType (lan-ip mode and hostname mode, with lan-ip mode as default))
members.name: Property

members.document: Number of primary nodes currently in the cluster
members.name: ClusterMaterNodeNum

members.document:
ID of the image used by the cluster
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: ImageId

members.document:
Container image tag
Note: This field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: OsCustomizeType

members.document:
Runtime environment of the cluster. Values can be `docker` or `containerd`.
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: ContainerRuntime

members.document:
Creation time
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: CreatedTime

members.document:
Whether Deletion Protection is enabled
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: DeletionProtection

members.document: Whether IPVS is enabled
members.name: IPVS

members.document: Whether auto-scaling is enabled for nodes in the cluster (Enabling this function is not supported when you create a cluster)
members.name: AsEnabled

members.document: Type of runtime component used by the cluster. The types include "docker" and "containerd". Default value: docker
members.name: ContainerRuntime

members.document: NodeName type for a node in a cluster (This includes the two forms of **hostname** and **lan-ip**, with the default as **lan-ip**. If **hostname** is used, you need to set the HostName parameter when creating a node, and the InstanceName needs to be the same as the HostName.)
members.name: NodeNameType

members.document: Cluster custom parameter
members.name: ExtraArgs

members.document: Cluster network type, which can be GR (Global Router) or VPC-CNI. The default value is GR.
members.name: NetworkType

members.document: Whether a cluster in VPC-CNI mode uses dynamic IP addresses. The default value is FALSE, which indicates that static IP addresses are used.
members.name: IsNonStaticIpMode

members.document: Indicates whether to enable cluster deletion protection.
members.name: DeletionProtection

members.document:
Cluster network proxy model, which is only used when ipvs-bpf mode is used. At present, TKE cluster supports three network proxy modes including `iptables`, `ipvs` and `ipvs-bpf` and their parameter setting relationships are as follows:
`iptables`: do not set IPVS and KubeProxyMode.
`ipvs`: set IPVS to `true` and do not set KubeProxyMode.
`ipvs-bpf`: set KubeProxyMode to `kube-proxy-bpf`.
The following conditions are required to use ipvs-bpf network mode:
1. The cluster version must be v1.14 or later.
2. The system image must be Tencent Linux 2.4.
members.name: KubeProxyMode

members.document: Indicates whether to enable auditing
members.name: AuditEnabled

members.document: Specifies the ID of logset to which the audit logs are uploaded.
members.name: AuditLogsetId

members.document: Specifies the ID of topic to which the audit logs are uploaded.
members.name: AuditLogTopicId

members.document: Specifies whether the VPC CNI type is multi-IP ENI or or independent ENI.
members.name: VpcCniType

members.document: Runtime version
members.name: RuntimeVersion

members.document: Indicates whether to enable the custom mode for the node’s pod CIDR range
members.name: EnableCustomizedPodCIDR

members.document: The basic number of Pods in custom mode
members.name: BasePodNumber

members.document: Scaling group ID
members.name: AutoScalingGroupId

members.document: Scaling group status (`enabled`, `enabling`, `disabled`, `disabling`, `updating`, `deleting`, `scaleDownEnabling`, `scaleDownDisabling`)
members.name: Status

members.document:
Whether the node is set to unschedulable
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: IsUnschedulable

members.document:
Scaling group label list
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: Labels

members.document: Creation time
members.name: CreatedTime

members.document: Scaling group ID
members.name: AutoScalingGroupId

members.document: Whether it is enabled
members.name: AutoScalingGroupEnabled

members.document: Maximum and minimum number of pods in a scaling group
members.name: AutoScalingGroupRange

members.document:
Whether to enable scale-in
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: IsScaleDownEnabled

members.document:
The scale-out method when there are multiple scaling groups. `random`: select a random scaling group. `most-pods`: choose the scaling group that can schedule the most pods. `least-waste`: select the scaling group that can ensure the fewest remaining resources after Pod scheduling.. The default value is `random`.)
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: Expander

members.document:
Max concurrent scale-in volume
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: MaxEmptyBulkDelete

members.document:
Number of minutes after cluster scale-out when the system starts judging whether to perform scale-in
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: ScaleDownDelay

members.document:
Number of consecutive minutes of idleness after which the node is subject to scale-in (default value: 10)
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: ScaleDownUnneededTime

members.document:
Percentage of node resource usage below which the node is considered to be idle (default value: 50)
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: ScaleDownUtilizationThreshold

members.document:
During scale-in, ignore nodes with local storage pods (default value: False)
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: SkipNodesWithLocalStorage

members.document:
During scale-in, ignore nodes with pods in the kube-system namespace that are not managed by DaemonSet (default value: False)
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: SkipNodesWithSystemPods

members.document:
Whether to ignore DaemonSet pods by default when calculating resource usage (default value: False: do not ignore)
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: IgnoreDaemonSetsUtilization

members.document:
Number at which CA health detection is triggered (default value: 3). After the number specified in OkTotalUnreadyCount is exceeded, CA will perform health detection.
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: OkTotalUnreadyCount

members.document:
Max percentage of unready nodes. After the max percentage is exceeded, CA will stop operation.
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: MaxTotalUnreadyPercentage

members.document:
Amount of time before unready nodes become eligible for scale-in
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: ScaleDownUnreadyTime

members.document:
Waiting time before CA deletes nodes that are not registered in Kubernetes
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: UnregisteredNodeRemovalTime

ClusterBasicSettings.document: Describes the basic configuration information of a cluster

members.document: Cluster operating system. CentOS 7.2x86_64 or Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTSx86_64. Default value: Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTSx86_64
members.name: ClusterOs

members.document: Cluster version. The default value is 1.10.5.
members.name: ClusterVersion

members.document: Cluster name
members.name: ClusterName

members.document: Cluster description
members.name: ClusterDescription

members.document: VPC ID, in the format of vpc-xxx, which is required when you create an empty managed cluster.
members.name: VpcId

members.document: ID of the project to which the new resources in the cluster belong.
members.name: ProjectId

members.document: Tag description list. This parameter is used to bind a tag to a resource instance. Currently, a tag can only be bound to cluster instances.
members.name: TagSpecification

members.document: Container image tag, `DOCKER_CUSTOMIZE` (container customized tag), `GENERAL` (general tag, default value)
members.name: OsCustomizeType

members.document: Whether to enable the node’s default security group (default: `No`, Aphla feature)
members.name: NeedWorkSecurityGroup

ClusterCIDRSettings.document: Container networking parameters for the cluster

members.document: CIDR used to assign container and service IPs for the cluster. It cannot conflict with the VPC's CIDR or the CIDRs of other clusters in the same VPC
members.name: ClusterCIDR

members.document: Whether to ignore ClusterCIDR conflict errors, which are not ignored by default
members.name: IgnoreClusterCIDRConflict

members.document: Maximum number of pods on each node in the cluster
members.name: MaxNodePodNum

members.document: Maximum number of cluster services
members.name: MaxClusterServiceNum

members.document: The CIDR block used to assign cluster service IP addresses. It must conflict with neither the VPC CIDR block nor with CIDR blocks of other clusters in the same VPC instance. The IP range must be within the private network IP range, such as 10.1.0.0/14, 192.168.0.1/18, and 172.16.0.0/16.
members.name: ServiceCIDR

members.document: Subnet ID of the ENI in VPC-CNI network mode
members.name: EniSubnetIds

members.document: Repossession time of ENI IP addresses in VPC-CNI network mode, whose range is [300,15768000)
members.name: ClaimExpiredSeconds

members.document:
kube-apiserver custom parameter, in the format of ["k1=v1", "k1=v2"], for example: ["max-requests-inflight=500","feature-gates=PodShareProcessNamespace=true,DynamicKubeletConfig=true"].
Note: this field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: KubeAPIServer

members.document:
kube-controller-manager custom parameter
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: KubeControllerManager

members.document:
kube-scheduler custom parameter
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: KubeScheduler

members.document:
etcd custom parameter, which is only effective for self-deployed cluster.
Note: this field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: Etcd

members.document: CIDR used to assign container and service IPs for the cluster. It cannot conflict with the VPC's CIDR or the CIDRs of other clusters in the same VPC.
members.name: ClusterCIDR

members.document: Whether to ignore ClusterCIDR conflict errors. It defaults to not ignore.
members.name: IgnoreClusterCIDRConflict

members.document: Maximum number of pods on each node in the cluster. Default value: 256
members.name: MaxNodePodNum

members.document: Maximum number of cluster services. Default value: 256
members.name: MaxClusterServiceNum

members.document: Whether IPVS is enabled. Default value: disabled
members.name: Ipvs

members.document: Cluster VPC ID, which is required when you create an empty cluster; otherwise, it is automatically set to be consistent with that of the nodes in the cluster
members.name: VpcId

members.document: Whether CNI is enabled for network plugin(s). Default value: enabled
members.name: Cni

members.document: Cluster ID
members.name: ClusterId

members.document: The list of cluster major version, such as 1.18.4
members.name: Versions

members.document: Cluster ID
members.name: ClusterId

members.document: The pass-through parameters for scaling group creation, in the format of a JSON string. For more information, see the [CreateAutoScalingGroup](https://intl.cloud.tencent.com/document/api/377/20440?from_cn_redirect=1) API. The **LaunchConfigurationId** is created with the LaunchConfigurePara parameter, which does not support data entry.

Filter.document:
> Key-value pair filters used for conditional queries, such as filtering results by ID, name, and state.
> * If there are multiple `Filter` parameters, they are evaluated using the logical `AND` operator.
> * If a `Filter` contains multiple `Values`, they are evaluated using the logical `OR` operator.
>
> Take [DescribeInstances](https://intl.cloud.tencent.com/document/api/213/15728?from_cn_redirect=1) as an example. You can use the following filters to query the instances in availability zone (`zone`) Guangzhou Zone 1 ***and*** whose billing plan (`instance-charge-type`) is pay-as-you-go:
```
Filters.0.Name=zone
&Filters.0.Values.0=ap-guangzhou-1
&Filters.1.Name=instance-charge-type
&Filters.1.Values.0=POSTPAID_BY_HOUR
```

members.document: Filters.
members.name: Name

InstanceAdvancedSettings.document: Describes K8s cluster configuration and related information.

members.document:
Data disk mount point. By default, no data disk is mounted. Data disks in ext3, ext4, or XFS file system formats will be mounted directly, while data disks in other file systems and unformatted data disks will automatically be formatted as ext4 (xfs for tlinux system) and then mounted. Please back up your data in advance. This setting is only applicable to CVMs with a single data disk.
Note: in multi-disk scenarios, use the DataDisks data structure below to set the corresponding information, such as cloud disk type, cloud disk size, mount path, and whether to perform formatting.
Note: this field may return `null`, indicating that no valid values can be obtained.
members.name: MountTarget

members.document:
Specified value of dockerd --graph. Default value: /var/lib/docker
Note: This field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: DockerGraphPath

members.document:
Base64-encoded user script, which will be executed after the K8s component starts running. You need to ensure the reentrant and retry logic of the script. The script and its log files can be viewed at the node path: /data/ccs_userscript/. If you want to initialize nodes before adding them to the scheduling list, you can use this parameter together with the unschedulable parameter. After the final initialization of userScript is completed, add the kubectl uncordon nodename --kubeconfig=/root/.kube/config command to enable the node for scheduling.
Note: This field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: UserScript

members.document: Sets whether the added node is schedulable. 0 (default): schedulable; other values: unschedulable. After node initialization is completed, you can run kubectl uncordon nodename to enable this node for scheduling.
members.name: Unschedulable

members.document:
Node label array
Note: This field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: Labels

members.document:
Mounting information of multiple data disks. Ensure that the CVM purchase parameter specifies the information required for the purchase of multiple data disks, for example `DataDisks` under `RunInstancesPara` of the `CreateClusterInstances` API. You can refer to the example of adding a cluster node with multiple data disks in the CreateClusterInstances API. This parameter does not take effect when the AddExistedInstances API is called.
Note: this field may return `null`, indicating that no valid values can be obtained.
members.name: DataDisks

members.document:
Information about node custom parameters
Note: This field may return null, indicating that no valid value was found.
members.name: ExtraArgs

Note: this field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: Kubelet

LoginSettings.document: Describes login settings of an instance.

members.document:
Login password of the instance. The password requirements vary among different operating systems:
  • For Linux instances, the password must be 8-30 characters long and contain at least two of the following types: [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9] and [( ) \` ~ ! @ # $ % ^ & * - + = | { } [ ] : ; ' , . ? / ].
  • For Windows instances, the password must be 12-30 characters long and contain at least three of the following categories: [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9] and [( ) \` ~ ! @ # $ % ^ & * - + = | { } [ ] : ; ' , . ? /].

    If this parameter is not specified, a random password will be generated and sent to you via the Message Center. Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: Password

members.document:
List of key IDs. After an instance is associated with a key, you can access the instance with the private key in the key pair. You can call [`DescribeKeyPairs`](https://intl.cloud.tencent.com/document/api/213/15699?from_cn_redirect=1) to obtain `KeyId`. A key and password cannot be specified at the same time. Windows instances do not support keys. Currently, you can only specify one key when purchasing an instance.
Note: this field may return null, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: KeyIds

members.document:
Whether to keep the original settings of an image. You cannot specify this parameter and `Password` or `KeyIds.N` at the same time. You can specify this parameter as `TRUE` only when you create an instance using a custom image, a shared image, or an imported image. Valid values:
  • TRUE: keep the login settings of the image
  • FALSE: do not keep the login settings of the image

    Default value: FALSE. Note: This field may return null, indicating that no valid value is found.
members.name: KeepImageLogin

RunInstancesForNode.document: Node configuration parameters of different roles

members.document: Node role. Values: MASTER_ETCD, WORKER. You only need to specify MASTER_ETCD when creating a self-deployed cluster (INDEPENDENT_CLUSTER).
members.name: NodeRole

members.document: Pass-through parameter for CVM creation in the format of a JSON string. For more information, see the API for [creating a CVM instance](https://intl.cloud.tencent.com/document/product/213/15730?from_cn_redirect=1). Pass any parameter other than common parameters. ImageId will be replaced with the image corresponding to the TKE cluster operating system.
members.name: RunInstancesPara

members.document: An advanced node setting. This parameter overrides the InstanceAdvancedSettings item set at the cluster level and corresponds to RunInstancesPara in a one-to-one sequential manner (currently valid for the ExtraArgs node custom parameter only).
members.name: InstanceAdvancedSettingsOverrides

RunMonitorServiceEnabled.document: Describes information related to the Cloud Monitor service.

members.document:
Whether to enable [Cloud Monitor](https://intl.cloud.tencent.com/document/product/248?from_cn_redirect=1). Valid values:
  • TRUE: enable Cloud Monitor
  • FALSE: do not enable Cloud Monitor

    Default value: TRUE.
members.name: Enabled

RunSecurityServiceEnabled.document: Describes information related to the Cloud Security service.

members.document:
Whether to enable [Cloud Security](https://intl.cloud.tencent.com/document/product/296?from_cn_redirect=1). Valid values:
  • TRUE: enable Cloud Security
  • FALSE: do not enable Cloud Security

    Default value: TRUE.
members.name: Enabled

members.document: The type of resource that the tag is bound to. The type currently supported is `cluster`.
members.name: ResourceType

members.document: Step name

members.document:
Lifecycle
pending: the step is not started
running: the step is in progress
success: the step is completed
failed: the step failed
members.name: LifeState

Step start time
Note: this field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: StartAt

members.document:
Step end time
Note: this field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value is obtained.
members.name: EndAt

If the lifecycle of the step is failed, this field will display the error information.
Note: this field may return `null`, indicating that no valid value is obtained.

members.document: Cluster ID

members.document:
create: starting an upgrade task
pause: pausing the task
resume: continuing the task
abort: stopping the task
members.name: Operation

members.document:
Upgrade type. It’s only required when `Operation` is set as `create`.
reset: the reinstallation and upgrade of major version
hot: the hot upgrade of minor version
major: in-place upgrade of major version
members.name: UpgradeType

members.document: List of nodes that need to upgrade
members.name: InstanceIds

members.document: This parameter is used when the node joins the cluster again. Refer to the API of creating one or more cluster nodes.
members.name: ResetParam

members.document: Whether to skip the pre-upgrade check of the node
members.name: SkipPreCheck

members.document: The maximum tolerable proportion of unavailable pods
members.name: MaxNotReadyPercent

members.name: RequestId

members.document: Additional parameters set for the instance
members.name: InstanceAdvancedSettings

members.document: Enhanced services. You can use this parameter to specify whether to enable services such as Cloud Security and Cloud Monitor. If this parameter is not specified, Cloud Monitor and Cloud Security will be enabled by default.
members.name: EnhancedService

members.document: Node login information. For now, it only supports Password or a single KeyIds
members.name: LoginSettings

members.document: Security group to which the instance belongs. This parameter can be obtained from the `sgId` field in the response of `DescribeSecurityGroups`. If this parameter is not specified, the default security group is bound. (Currently, you can only set a single sgId.)
members.name: SecurityGroupIds
